thread.title: Norwich 0 West Brom 1 - Report and pictures
thread.title_full: Norwich 0 West Brom 1 - Report and pictures

title: Norwich 0 West Brom 1 - Report and pictures
text:
Tweet 
Picking up back-to-back victories for the first time this campaign, Tony Pulis' side were forced to weather an early storm from a Norwich side which came flying out of the traps. 
But the Baggies slowly grew into the game and after a breathless first half somehow ended goalless despite both teams having a host of chances, Rondon's header from James McClean's cross proved enough to win the fixture and lift Albion into the top half for today at least. 
Sticking with the team that picked up a first home win last week, Tony Pulis named an unchanged side, rewarding Stephane Sessegnon for his man of the match performance against Sunderland with another start. 
His decision was made easier by James Morrison's slow recovery from an ankle injury, and for the second week running the Scotsman was ommitted from the match day squad entirely. 
Former Albion midfielder Graham Dorrans was dropped to the Norwich bench in favour of the returning Wes Hoolahan, and the game came around too quickly for Youssouf Mulumbu, who's yet to play a competitive fixture for the Canaries since picking up a fractured foot in pre-season. 
It was Hoolahan who had the first shot of the game three minutes in, blasting over from the egde of the box during a frenetic start to proceedings after Nathan Redmond laid off Matt Jarvis' low cross. 
Chris Brunt forced John Ruddy to push his long-range effort away soon after, but Norwich skampered back up the other end and created another chance, this time for Jonny Howson, who also skied his effort from just outside the box uselessly over the bar. 
Carrow Road was jumping though, and a quarter of an hour in Hoolahan drilled a gorgeous cross-field ball to Redmond at the back post leaving him one-on-one with Brunt. 
Although the 21-year-old winger beat Albion's left-back on the outside, his low cross-cum-shot from a narrow angle was palmed clear by a strong Myhill hand. 
It took more than 20 minutes for the home side to settle down, and Albion eventually enjoyed a spell of pressure in the Canaries' half after Howson was booked for fouling Saido Berahino on the half-way line. 
Two Chris Brunt crosses came to nothing, but when Albion won a free-kick 30 yards out they nearly worked it into a goal with a training ground routine. 
Sessegnon touched the ball to James McClean, who faked to shoot before feeding Dawson on the overlap. 
The full-back's dangerous low pass across the face of goal was crying out to be turned in but it was just too quick for Salomon Rondon sliding it at the back post. 
Norwich were having joy down the left wing through Jarvis, and on 35 minutes his inviting cross was turned over by Redmond on the half-volley from seven yards out. 
It was another let-off for the Baggies, but Pulis' side had the best chance of the half two minutes before the break when Dawson met Sessegnon's inswinging corner. 
With the goal gaping in front of him somehow the full-back managed to head the ball down into the ground and over the bar from just four yards out to the disbelief of the travelling supporters. 
There was still time for Myhill to smother Mbokani's close-range shot and Rondon to put a header over the bar from Brunt's deep cross before a breathless first half came to a close. 
The second half started just as fast, and Albion took the lead almost immediately. 
Chris Brunt won the ball inside the centre circle and fed Saido Berahino in the left channel. The striker held the ball up before laying off McClean on the overlap and when the Derry winger clipped in a cross to the back post, Rondon dived in front of Bassong and headed home his second goal of the season before wheeling away to celebrate with the sold-out section of away fans in the corner. 
Like last week, the goal gave Albion some confidence, and they started to zip the ball around in midfield after that. 
Only a full-stretch save from Ruddy stopped Brunt from thundering in a second goal with his right-foot in the 64th minute, while Berahino and Rondon gave the Norwich keeper some nervy moments with their willingness to chase down the ball. 
Hoolahan scuffed an effort from the edge of the box and Ryan Bennett put a header at the back post wide, but the Albion back four limited the home side to little else apart from that for the majority of the second half. 
Norwich's best chance came six minutes from time when Alex Tettey put a header from a corner over fromjust six yards out but this Albion side are frugal at the back and they held on for the sixth clean sheet of the season and all three points. 
NORWICH (4-4-1-1): Ruddy, Martin (c), Bassong, Bennett, Brady, Jarvis, Tettey, Howson, Redmond, Hoolahan, Mbokani. Subs: Rudd, Whittaker, Grabban, Jerome, Dorrans, Olsson, O'Neil. 
ALBION (4-4-2): Myhill, Brunt, McAuley, Evans, Dawson, Yacob, Fletcher (c), McClean, Berahino, Sessegnon, Rondon. Subs: Lindegaard, Olsson, Chester, Gardner, Anichebe, Lambert, McManaman. What do you think?
